Introduction

Fragile X syndrome (FXS) is the most common inherited cause of intellectual disability and a significant genetic cause of autism spectrum disorder (ASD).  It is an X-linked disorder caused by a mutation in the FMR1 gene on the X chromosome.

Pathogenesis



FXS is due to an unstable CGG trinucleotide repeat expansion in the FMR1 gene on the long arm of the X chromosome (

figure 1
).  FMR1 normally has 6-50 CGG trinucleotide repeats in the 5â€² untranslated region that can potentially expand during meiosis in oocytes.  Expansion over generations can lead to >200 CGG trinucleotide repeats (ie, full mutation).  This mutation causes hypermethylation of the gene, which silences the gene and prevents transcription of the associated fragile X messenger ribonucleoprotein (FMRP).  Because FMRP is involved in the development and plasticity of neurons, silencing of the gene in FXS results in impaired neural development.



The name "fragile X" comes from the fact that, when the cells of affected individuals are cultured in a folate-deficient medium, the area of increased repeats does not stain and appears "broken" with a small gap near the tip of the long arm of the X chromosome (hence, fragile X).

Genetics and risk factors



FXS is an X-linked dominant disorder.  The primary risk factor is a family history of the disorder.  Female carriers of the FMR1 premutation (55-200 CGG repeats) are at risk of having offspring with FXS.  Male carriers may pass the premutation to all of their daughters.  With the full mutation (>200 CGG repeats), males are more severely affected than females due to the presence of only one X chromosome.  Females with the full mutation usually have milder symptoms due to random X-inactivation (eg, silencing of one of the X chromosomes in each cell).

Clinical presentation



Male individuals typically manifest the features of FXS, whereas female individuals have a milder and variable presentation.  Classic findings in male patients include:

Physical features



  • A long, narrow face (
    figure 2
    )
  • Prominent forehead and chin
  • Large ears
  • Deep-set eyes
  • Macroorchidism (eg, large testes)

Neuropsychiatric issues



  • Attention deficit hyperactivity disorder (ADHD) (eg, inattention, impulsivity)
  • ASD (eg, poor eye contact, social deficits)
  • Aggression, anxiety, and self-injurious behavior (eg, hand-biting)

Developmental delay and/or intellectual disability



These can range in severity from mild to severe.



Infants and young children typically present with subtle signs of FXS.  They may present with a mild developmental delay, including delayed achievement of motor and language milestones.  Delayed language development is the most common finding, with particular difficulty in expressive language.  Approximately 10% of children with FXS are completely nonverbal.  Neurobehavioral features, such as ADHD and ASD, may become apparent in early childhood.  Other physical signs that may be present in younger children include macrocephaly, joint hyperlaxity, hypotonia, and midface hypoplasia with sunken eyes.  Some children with FXS (~15%) may develop focal seizures.



The major physical findings of FXS are subtle until puberty, at which time macroorchidism and dysmorphic facies (eg, long, narrow face; prominent forehead and chin) become more noticeable.  Testicular enlargement is typically seen sometime after age 8; although the testes appear large, they typically have normal function.



Females with the full mutation typically have less severe symptoms because random X inactivation occurs in girls.  About half of girls with the full mutation have normal intellectual functioning, whereas the other half have mild intellectual disability.  Many have subtle learning difficulties.  Physical features are usually not as apparent in females but may include primary ovarian insufficiency (ie, absent menses at age <40).

Differential diagnosis



The differential diagnosis (

) of FXS includes the following:



  • Down syndrome (trisomy 21):  is associated with ASD and intellectual disability.  However, the diagnosis is usually suspected during prenatal screening or in infancy due to the characteristic dysmorphic features, including a short neck, low-set ears, and epicanthal folds that are present at birth.
  • Angelman syndrome (loss of maternal allele on chromosome 15q11-q13):  is associated with ASD and severe intellectual disability but typically presents with microcephaly, motor impairments, and inappropriate laughter, which are not seen in patients with FXS.
  • Prader-Willi syndrome (loss of paternal allele on chromosome 15q11-q13):  is also a genetic cause of ASD but typically presents with obesity (hyperphagia), cryptorchidism (not macroorchidism), and short stature in childhood.
  • Rett syndrome:  is caused by a mutation in the MECP2 gene.  This syndrome can cause autistic features, but it typically presents almost exclusively in females with normal initial development followed by regression in communication at age 12-18 months.  An abnormal gait is also seen.
  • Klinefelter syndrome (47,XXY):  is a sex chromosome aneuploidy, in which patients often have mild intellectual disability and neurobehavioral issues.  However, small (not large) testes are expected, and dysmorphic facial features are not typical.

Diagnosis



In patients with suspected FXS, a detailed history and physical examination focusing on cognitive issues and dysmorphic features are key.  Parental history of similar symptoms or family history of intellectual disability supports the diagnosis.  However, because of its inheritance, female individuals in the family may have a mild phenotype, so in some cases, history may be unrevealing.



Early developmental assessments that evaluate for developmental delay, as well as validated screening tools for ASD between 18-24 months, are often used in pediatric well-child checks; these can be useful for identifying delays or ASD symptoms that may prompt further testing.  Almost all patients with ASD, intellectual disability, or development delay without a known etiology should undergo standard FXS testing.



The gold standard for diagnosing FXS is FMR1 DNA analysis with PCR followed by Southern blot analysis to measure the CGG repeat length.

Management



The mainstay of management of FXS is individualized and typically involves multiple psychosocial and educational interventions.  Behavior, speech, and occupational therapies can be used to improve daily functioning.  Individualized education plans can be implemented by schools to provide learning accommodations.  Much of the management of FXS involves managing ASD and ADHD.  Medications may be used to manage symptoms such as anxiety, ADHD, and mood instability.  Genetic counseling is important for families to understand the risks of their children inheriting the disorder and the implications of having FXS.

Prognosis



Patients with FXS have a normal life expectancy; however, individuals have varying degrees of intellectual disability that may affect their ability to perform activities of daily living.  Prompt diagnosis with genetic testing allows for early implementation of developmental and behavioral therapies that can help patients with quality of life.

Summary



Fragile X syndrome (
